Many Minnetonka High School students, while balancing the challenges of COVID-19 and e-learning, have continued to act as essential workers in the Minnetonka community. Today we want to recognize Lucia Hill, Barista at Starbucks.

Lucia is a graduating senior at MHS and has been working at Starbucks since last September.

Starbucks, like many companies, has taken measures to ensure employee and customer safety. Masks and added cleaning are a must, and the only transactions that can be made are at the drive thru. But due to a pre-existing condition, Lucia has taken extra precautions. " I returned to work at the beginning of May and because of my health risk I don't have to come into contact with anyone other than my coworkers," she says.

Lucia realizes that coffee might not seem essential during these times, but she knows that her work has at least "given people something to do. I understand the boredom people are facing and how getting out of the house to go do something is really critical for people's sanity."

Many Minnetonka High School students, while balancing the challenges of COVID-19 and e-learning, have continued to act as essential workers in the Minnetonka community. Today we want to recognize Conor Abrahamson, Worker at Valvoline Instant Oil Change

Conor is a rising senior at MHS and has been working at Valvoline Instant Oil Change for about 4 months.

Connor says Valvoline has taken some measures to ensure employee and customer safety. "At all times we are now required to be checked by a non-contact infrared thermometer," he says, "and we have to clean the store every three hours." In addition, he and his co-workers have been using masks and latex gloves regularly.

"I never thought I'd be an essential worker," Connor admits, but he does acknowledge the impact his work has for the community. " I'm keeping cars on the road and ultimately the community moving forward," he says.

When Service Club Imagine partnered with Cheerful Givers to facilitate a toy drive at MHS, Minnetonka Middle School West and Excelsior Elementary in February, they hoped to gather enough to create 50 birthday presents for kids in need. Instead, they received enough for 150 bags, three times their original goal!

Aileen Dosev, a freshman at MHS and the club founder, distributed the gifts to food shelves and shelters in Waconia, Eagan, Eden Prairie and St. Paul.

“I've learned much by running this drive,” shared Aileen. “It has helped me improve my leadership, organization, and communication skills. Most importantly, it's helped me realize how important acknowledging and celebrating a person's life is. Myself and others who can afford to have birthdays don't fully understand how much a present can do for a child's self esteem and confidence.”

Read more here: https://bit.ly/ServiceClubImagineToyDrive

Minnetonka Schools and Moving Minds by Gopher Sport, a K-12 furniture company based in Owatonna, have been named Cultural Transformation finalists for the 2020 Design and Innovation Awards. “This partnership was a chance for corporate and nonprofit entities to share in solving problems together, with our focus being on student development and learning,” shared Nicole Snedden, Innovation Coordinator for Minnetonka Schools.

The D&I Awards honor, recognize and promote individuals and teams who have made a commitment to driving superior contact center and UX performance. Other finalists in the Cultural Transformation category include EATON, IBM, Pitney Bowes and the American Dental Association. Award winners will be announced in September 2020 at the Design Thinking Summit.

We are proud of you and grateful for your hard work to be your best for your students!

Maggie is a four-year letter winner and two-year captain for the Minnetonka Skippers Girls Hockey Team. She has helped lead the Skippers to two section 2AA championships in 2019 and 2020, and, subsequently, helped lead the Minnetonka Skippers to back to back 3rd place finishes at the state tournament in 2019 and 2020. Maggie has earned four all conference awards and was named a Ms. Hockey finalist in 2020. She has represented the United States for three years on the Under-18 Women's National Team at world competition. As a captain, Maggie led the 2020 National Team to a gold medal.

Next year, Maggie will attend the University of Minnesota and play hockey for the Gophers.

Students need to create technology, not just consume it.

Minnetonka Girls Hockey kept us on the edge of our seats again this year.

The girls were ranked number three in the state all season and clinched a second straight Section 2AA title with a 6-2 win over Eden Prairie. Minnetonka then opened the Class AA State Tournament at the Xcel Energy Center with a dramatic 7-2 win over Roseau. In the semifinal game against Andover, it was clear early on that anything could happen. The teams fought incredibly hard and it was a lightning-fast goal in overtime that gave Andover the win.

Our girls kept up the momentum to earn the State Third Place honor with a 3-1 win over Maple Grove.

We also had some incredible recognition for individual players:

- Senior Maggie Nicholson was named one of 10 Ms. Hockey finalists
- Rory Guilday and Maggie Nicholson were named to 2020 Star Tribune All-Metro First Team and the Class AA All-State team
- Brynn DuLac was named to the Class AA Honorable Mention team
- Brynn DuLac, Maggie Nicholson, and Hannah Baskin were part of the Class AA Wells Fargo All-Tournament Team

Congratulations on an amazing season!

Remember to turn your clocks ahead an hour this weekend! Sunday, March 8th marks Daylight Saving Time, so get ready to Spring Forward!

A few interesting facts about DST:

- You lose an hour of sleep, but gain some extra sunshine in the evening.

- In addition to the U.S. territories of Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands and Guam, the states of Hawaii and Arizona do not observe DST.

- Some countries around the world observe DST, some do not, and some did for a while but don’t anymore.

- It’s actually called daylight saving time, not savings.

Students participate in health science-related experiences to understand future employment opportunities in this growing sector of the economy. In addition to their coursework in AP Psychology and Human Anatomy, students can earn certification as a nursing assistant registered or emergency medical responder. This certification gives students advanced training and a jump-start in the field of health care.
Students receive regular guest instruction and attend site visits with health science leaders such as the University of Minnesota, Children’s Minnesota and Excelen Center for Bone & Joint Research. Students gain a firm understanding of psychology and the human system, including a generalist view of the many professions available as a prospective health care professional. This program is offered to juniors and seniors.

Students engage in real-world experiences in the fields related to global sustainability. They learn and grow in areas that offer future employment such as corporate sustainability, food science, food security, food safety, water systems, waste system, energy conservation and others. Coursework integrates physical, biological and information sciences to the study of the environment and global economics.
Students spend both semesters working on a variety of industry-driven projects, solving research problems and learning about the challenges and rewards of project-based work. They also learn about economics and the policy implications of food sustainability, with an emphasis on the global nature of food production and its impact on communities and the environment. This program is offered to juniors and seniors.
